title: Complex systems and bridging between spec and implementation
description:
I am on the cusp (hopefully) of kicking off development of a fairly large and complex system (multiple integrated services, kafkas involved, background processes, multiple client frontends, etc‚Ä¶). It‚Äôs predominantly going to be built in rust (but that‚Äôs only trivially relevant; i.e. not following standard OOP).

Here‚Äôs where i‚Äôm at:

  1. I have defined all the components, services, data stores to use / or develop
  2. I have a a fairly concrete conceptualisation of how to structure and manage data on the storage end of the system which i‚Äôm formalizing into a specification
  3. I have a deployment model for the various parts of the system to go into production

The problem is, I have a gap, from these specs of the individual components and services that need to be built out, to the actual implementation of those services. I‚Äôve scaffolded the code-base around what ‚Äúfeels‚Äù like sensible semantics, but bridging from the scope, through the high-level code organisation through to implementation is where I start to get a bit queasy.

In the past, i‚Äôve more or less dove head-first into just starting to implement, but the problem has been that I will very easily end up going in circles, or I end up with a lot of duplicated code across areas and just generally feel like it‚Äôs not working out the way I had hoped (obviously because i‚Äôve just gone ahead and implemented).

What are some tools, processes, design concepts, thinking patterns that you can use to sort of fill in that ‚Äúlast mile‚Äù from high-level spec to implementing to try and ensure that things stay on track and limit abandonment or going down dead-ends?

I‚Äôm interested in advice, articles, books, or anything else that makes sense in the rough context above. Not specifically around for instance design patterns themselves, i‚Äôm more than familiar with the tools in that arsenal, but how do you bridge the gap between the concept and the implementation without going too deep down the rabbit-hole of modelling out actual code and everything else in UML for instance? How do you basically minimize getting mired in massive refactors once you get to implementation phase?
description_plain:
I am on the cusp (hopefully) of kicking off development of a fairly large and complex system (multiple integrated services, kafkas involved, background processes, multiple client frontends, etc...). It's predominantly going to be built in rust (but that's only trivially relevant; i.e. not following standard OOP).

Here's where i'm at:

1. I have defined all the components, services, data stores to use / or develop
2. I have a a fairly concrete conceptualisation of how to structure and manage data on the storage end of the system which i'm formalizing into a specification
3. I have a deployment model for the various parts of the system to go into production

The problem is, I have a gap, from these specs of the individual components and services that need to be built out, to the actual implementation of those services. I've scaffolded the code-base around what "feels" like sensible semantics, but bridging from the scope, through the high-level code organisation through to implementation is where I start to get a bit queasy.

In the past, i've more or less dove head-first into just starting to implement, but the problem has been that I will very easily end up going in circles, or I end up with a lot of duplicated code across areas and just generally feel like it's not working out the way I had hoped (obviously because i've just gone ahead and implemented).

What are some tools, processes, design concepts, thinking patterns that you can use to sort of fill in that "last mile" from high-level spec to implementing to try and ensure that things stay on track and limit abandonment or going down dead-ends?

I'm interested in advice, articles, books, or anything else that makes sense in the rough context above. Not specifically around for instance design patterns themselves, i'm more than familiar with the tools in that arsenal, but how do you bridge the gap between the concept and the implementation without going too deep down the rabbit-hole of modelling out actual code and everything else in UML for instance? How do you basically minimize getting mired in massive refactors once you get to implementation phase?
